item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“Maizez, post:11, topic:444980”]Cool thanks! Helped a lot.

one question.

Will I need to put the “c.” before each function that’s in the client file?[/quote]

if you’re calling it within client or player.java, then no.

if you’re calling a method that is in player or client then you would use “c.” if that’s what your instance of client.java is declared as

in the case above we used “Client c” as one of the parameters to our method “cleanText”, so we used c.sendFrameblahblah.

if you were to do this

public void example(Client assholerule) { assholerule.sendFrame126("dkdokfofko"); }

you can see how I didn’t use c that time, because it’s declared as assholerule

But I almost forgot, if you’re calling that method inside client.java

you would call it like this example(this);

EDIT:

some of the info i’m giving you might be wrong, didn’t realize you were running a deltascape source

Read full topic

item.title: Question about Initialize() function

@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Maizez, post:11, topic:444980”]Cool thanks! Helped a lot.

one question.

Will I need to put the “c.” before each function that’s in the client file?

Edit:
like “c.sendFrame126” because the sendFrame126 function is not in the Initialize file?[/quote]
Yes
Also, c.playerLevel and c.getLevelForXP

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

You don’t need the 'extends Player implements Runnable"

You can always just make a static method and reference it statically via

ClassNameHere.methodHere(parameters);

so if you were to use this

[code]package Server.Player;

import server.model.players.Client;

public class Initialize {

public static void cleanText(Client c) {
    int lineID[] = { 4004, 4008, 4006, 4016, 4010, 4012, 4014, 4034, 4038, 4026, 4032, 4036, 4024, 4030, 4028, 4020, 4018, 4022, 4152 };
    for(int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
        sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[i] + "", lineID[i]);
        sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[i]) + "", lineID[i] + 1);
    }
}

}
[/code]

You could call it like this

Read full topic

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @Maizez Maizez
item.description:
@Maizez wrote:

asshole_rule:

It’s up to you, I don’t think it matters, but if you want it to look cleaner, go ahead.

True… Do you think you could help me out on that one? I really have never created my own java.class file. I used to work in C# & VB.NET but I have no idea how I’d call functions and variables from that “Initialize.java” file.

So far here’s what’s in there:

package Server.Player;

public class Initialize extends Player implements Runnable {
	
}

I don’t even understand why it has “extends Player implements Runnable” I just put it there becuase it was also in my Client.java file

Read full topic

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“Maizez, post:7, topic:444980”]But that would be a problem lol… The ID for the line does not go in order.
For example, it goes 4013 then the next could be 4008. I’d have to make an array and then use that array in place of the ID.

int lineID[] = { 4004, 4008, 4006, 4016, 4010, 4012, 4014, 4034, 4038, 4026, 4032, 4036, 4024, 4030, 4028, 4020, 4018, 4022, 4152 };

Then:

for(int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
    sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[i] + "", lineID[i]);
    sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[i]) + "", lineID[i] + 1);
}

Ta-da for that

But… Doesn’t solve my original question.

If I want my client.java to look clean. Is it worth putting all of this in a seprate file and then just calling one function in my client.java file that points to that external “Initialize.java” file that contains all the functions needed for it?[/quote]

OH, I didn’t know they weren’t in order.

It’s up to you, I don’t think it matters, but if you want it to look cleaner, go ahead.

Read full topic

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @Maizez Maizez
item.description:
@Maizez wrote:

But that would be a problem lol… The ID for the line does not go in order.
For example, it goes 4013 then the next could be 4008. I’d have to make an array and then use that array in place of the ID.

int lineID[] = { 4004, 4008, 4006, 4016, 4010, 4012, 4014, 4034, 4038, 4026, 4032, 4036, 4024, 4030, 4028, 4020, 4018, 4022, 4152 };

Then:

for(int i = 0; i < 20; i++) {
    sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[i] + "", lineID[i]);
    sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[i]) + "", lineID[i] + 1);
}

Ta-da for that

But… Doesn’t solve my original question.

If I want my client.java to look clean. Is it worth putting all of this in a seprate file and then just calling one function in my client.java file that points to that external “Initialize.java” file that contains all the functions needed for it?

Read full topic

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“Maizez, post:5, topic:444980”][quote author=asshole_rule link=topic=547657.msg4015587#msg4015587 date=1339602269]
Yes you could or just shorten the code in general.

for(int i = 0; i < 20; i++) { sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[i] + "", 4004); sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[i]) + "", 4005); }

do that instead of making another class
[/quote]

Edit: The line numbers don’t go in incremental order/ and that loop wouldn’t ++ it either

Also that isn’t the only thing that is in there. There is ~350 lines of code. Different functions and stuff. Not just one thing.[/quote]

How am I supposed to know that if you only give 1 small part of the code, + that would work fine just add i to the string’s id.

Read full topic

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @Maizez Maizez
item.description:
@Maizez wrote:

ravekitty:

You could create a void outside of the initialize and then call it inside but I don’t think it would improve performance if that’s what you’re looking for =o

Exactly what I’m doing. I just want it to look neater. Can I make another file called “Initialize.java” and then put all my functions in there? Then in my client.java call the initialize function from the initialize.java file? It would only be one line of code in my client.java file instead of the 326 lines that I have at the moment.

Read full topic

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @ravekitty ravekitty
item.description:
@ravekitty wrote:

You could create a void outside of the initialize and then call it inside but I don’t think it would improve performance if that’s what you’re looking for =o

item.title: Question about Initialize() function
item.dc:creator: @Maizez Maizez
item.description:
@Maizez wrote:

Hello

I just don’t understand why there is so much stuff going on in my initialize function…

I am running on a clean DeltaScape source.

The question is, can I create functions outside of the initialize function and then call them in the function to make it look cleaner?
For example, I have things in there like:

		//send frames for stats
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[0] + "", 4004);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[0]) + "", 4005);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[1] + "", 4008);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[1]) + "", 4009);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[2] + "", 4006);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[2]) + "", 4007);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[3] + "", 4016);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[3]) + "", 4017);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[4] + "", 4010);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[4]) + "", 4011);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[5] + "", 4012);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[5]) + "", 4013);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[6] + "", 4014);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[6]) + "", 4015);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[7] + "", 4034);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[7]) + "", 4035);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[8] + "", 4038);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[8]) + "", 4039);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[9] + "", 4026);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[9]) + "", 4027);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[10] + "", 4032);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[10]) + "", 4033);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[11] + "", 4036);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[11]) + "", 4037);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[12] + "", 4024);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[12]) + "", 4025);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[13] + "", 4030);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[13]) + "", 4031);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[14] + "", 4028);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[14]) + "", 4029);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[15] + "", 4020);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[15]) + "", 4021);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[16], 4018);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[16]), 4019);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[17], 4022);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[17]), 4023);
		sendFrame126("" + playerLevel[20], 4152);
		sendFrame126("" + getLevelForXP(playerXP[20]), 4153);

You know what I mean?

Read full topic
